document_title: Monkeypox: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Monkeypox can be transmitted directly through contact with blood, body fluids, respiratory droplets, wounds on the skin or mucous membranes of a sick person (or of an infected animal).
In addition, eating meat from infected animals, contact with sick person's items (bedding, towels, clothes, etc.) or contact with skin lesions of a sick person can also cause an infection. people infected with monkeypox. Therefore, if you live with someone who has monkeypox, the chance of infection is often quite high. (3)
In addition, this disease can also be transmitted from mother to fetus and lead to congenital monkeypox. Newborns who come into close contact with their mothers during and after birth are also at high risk of infection if their mothers are sick.
Although close contact with sick people is considered a risk factor for spreading monkeypox, experts say it is still not possible to conclude whether this disease is sexually transmitted or not. More studies are needed to determine this issue.
Contact with a wound on the skin of an infected person can transmit monkeypox
